citeinfo.title: Water and Air Temperature Throughout the Range of Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout in Colorado and New Mexico; 2010-2015 V2

descript.abstract: This data set characterizes the thermal regime in a number of Colorado and New Mexico streams that contain populations of Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii virginalis) or have been considered potential restoration areas for the fish. The majority of these streams had no previous record of continual temperature records. When compared to Colorado water temperature criteria (Cold Tier 1), a portion of these populations appeared to be at risk from elevated stream temperatures, as indicated by exceedance of both acute and chronic water quality metrics. Summer water temperature profiles recorded at sites within current Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout habitat indicated that although the majority of currently occupied conservation streams have temperatures that fall well below these biologically based acute and chronic thermal thresholds, several sites may be at or approaching water temperatures considered stressful to Cutthroat Trout.
descript.purpose: The purpose of this data release is to provide general access to these stream temperature data sets. The dataset facilitates the comparison of stream temperature with the acute and chronic temperature threshold of Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout in order to identify at risk populations. This comparison can be used by managers for decisions regarding the current and future thermal suitability of existing Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout populations as well as potential restoration sites.

theme.themekey: Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout Colorado and New Mexico

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: There is no guarantee concerning the accuracy of the data. Any user who modifies the data is obligated to describe the types of modifications they perform. Data have been checked to ensure the accuracy. If any errors are detected, please notify the originating office. The U.S. Geological Survey strongly recommends that careful attention be paid to the metadata file associated with these data. Acknowledgment of the U.S. Geological Survey would be appreciated in products derived from these data. User specifically agrees not to misrepresent the data, nor to imply that changes made were approved or endorsed by the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to http://www.usgs.gov/privacy.html for the USGS disclaimer.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey Crustal Geophysics and Geochemistry Science Center

attracc.attraccr: Onset HOBO U22-001 Water Temperature Pro v2 Data Logger manufacturer specification information states a recording accuracy of +/- 0.2 degrees Celsius. Onset HOBO UA-002-64 Pendant Temperature/Light 64K Data Logger (Modified into STIC) manufacturer specification information states a recording accuracy of +/- 0.53 degrees Celsius. For more information on the STIC (Stream Temperature, Intermittency, and Conductivity logger), please visit http://www.onsetcomp.com/files/Chapin-STIC-WRR-2014-reprint.pdf . ThermoWorks LOGTAG Transit Recorder Model TW-TRIX-16 manufacturers specification information states a recording accuracy of +/- 1.0 degrees Celsius.

dataqual.logic: All water temp instruments were deployed in the stream thalweg. Water temperature data that recorded negative values indicates that the instrument was either frozen in ice or exposed to subzero air temperature due to stream intermittency. Data points that lack obvious diel variations in stream temperature are likely the result of the instrument being buried in sand or mud and limiting the direct circulation of stream water to the instrument.
dataqual.complete: Gaps in the data sets are the result of several factors; the site had not been established yet or was discontinued, an instrument was not deployed and recording at this time, the data record stopped due to device battery constraints, the data record stopped due to device memory constraints, the deployed instrument failed to record or encountered an error during recording, the deployed instrument failed to download or encountered an error during download, the deployed instrument and subsequent data record was lost due to possible theft or hydrologic events, or the download and replacement of an instrument results in a non-overlapping data record.

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

method.methdesc: Selection of study streams was informed by collaborative input provided by parties signatory to the Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout Conservation Agreement (Agreement), including the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish (NMDGF), Colorado Parks and Wildlife (CPW), the U.S. Forest Service (Santa Fe, Carson, and Rio Grande National Forests), the National Park Service (Great Sand Dunes National Park), local tribes (the Mescalero Apache Nation), and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) (RGCT Conservation Team, 2009). Initial selection of study streams was based on current Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout populations characterized by the signatories as high quality based on genetic purity, lack of nonnative Salmonids, and population size. Importantly, these streams were selected from a database of streams previously identified as containing Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout by signatories to the agreement, and independent validation of the presence of the fish was not conducted as part of this study. After initial site selection, several additional streams were added on the basis of requests from these State, Federal, and Tribal managers, including potential restoration sites, current restoration sites, or populations thought to be at risk because of a variety of threats related to future climate change. Within each stream, at least one paired stream/air site was selected at or near the downstream extent of a given conservation population. In general, monitoring sites located at the lowest extent of Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout populations were within occupied habitat unless otherwise prevented. Additional sites within a unique stream were selected on the basis of stream length and number of tributaries. For example, streams with occupied habitat of 8 km or greater, or those with unmonitored tributaries, warranted addition of sites to capture temperature variation because of the large spatial area. Within potential restoration streams, stream/air data loggers were deployed to correspond to elevations of data loggers within sites of nearby streams occupied by the subspecies. Certain stream conditions are known to cause thermal heterogeneity within a stream channel (such as tributaries, beaver ponds, groundwater seepage). To prevent deployment of data loggers into sites that would not accurately represent the thermal regime of the stream, data loggers were moved upstream or downstream to ensure thermal homogeneity. Study sites at population termini, however, were only moved upstream to ensure data loggers remained within occupied habitat. Temperature data loggers were deployed within the thalweg of deep well mixed habitats (as in runs), usually within areas covered by riparian vegetation. All the recording instruments were deployed in white PVC housing in order to reduce direct physical impact to the equipment and to eliminate the influence of direct solar radiation on temperature recording. Both air and stream temperature data loggers were programmed to record temperatures at 1-hour intervals, an interval which has been demonstrated to have a small probability of missing true daily maximum temperatures, even within streams exhibiting high daily variation in water temperature.

procstep.procdesc: Air temperature was recorded using a combination of LOGTAG and ProV2 devices. Water temperature was recorded using a combination of ProV2 and STIC devices.

An updated version (V2) of this data set was published on June 01, 2016. This update includs revised coordinates (UTM) for the following sites: Osha Canyon (20101UP02), NF Carnero Creek (10004NC02), NF Carnero Creek (10004NC03), NF Carnero Creek (10004NC04), Panchuela Creek (60001PC01), Jack's Creek (60001JC02), San Fransisco Creek (10002SF02).

Once devices were recovered from the field, data sets from the deployed instruments were downloaded using Onset HOBOware version 3.7.2 2002-2015 Onset Computer Corporation and further processed using Microsoft Excel version 14.0.7163.5000 Part of Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2010 Microsoft Corporation. The processing of each data set included trimming the pre-deployment and post-deployment record, and excluding outlier data points with a 1 hour interval difference greater than 3 degrees Celsius. The remaining data points were further examined and determined to be error free.

enttyp.enttypd: Dataset containing temperature measurements by site tab. Initial site description table contains site locations and notes.

Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the U.S. Geological Survey regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.
